Award.AwardTitle: Understanding Redox Reaction Mechanism and Dynamics at Single Nanoparticles Using ECL and Scanning Nanoelectrode with Improved Spatial and Spectral Resolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement & Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division of the NSF, Professor Shanlin Pan of The University of Alabama is developing electrochemistry and spectroscopy techniques to help address technical and scientific challenges of conventional electrochemistry methods for studying redox events at the nanometer scale. Combined methods of optical spectroscopy, nanoelectrochemistry, and imaging techniques will be used to address these challenges. The broader impacts are addressed in through outreach efforts focus on integrating the research project with education and training of high school teachers as well as education module development. The students working on this project will be part of an interdisciplinary team, and will be cross-trained in the areas of spectroelectrochemistry and material science. These skills will serve them well in their future careers. The proposed educational activities will help enhance the recruitment and retention of minority students and faculties in the Alabama area.

The proposal is designed to address both scientific and technical challenges for understanding detailed redox reaction mechanism and plasmon interaction with electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL) at single metallic nanoparticles (NPs) using improved spectroelectrochemistry techniques. Task-1 of the proposal involves the study of local electrochemical reaction and its temporal and spatial heterogeneities using ECL at single metallic NPs. Task-2 is designed to resolve the shape dependence of single NPs local electrochemical events with a scanning nanoelectrode probe method that has super-spatial resolution, beyond the optical diffraction limit, and reliable spectral resolution for probing local interfacial charge transfer events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is to develop electrochemistry and spectroscopy techniques to help address the technical and scientific challenges of conventional electrochemistry methods for studying redox events at the nanometer scale. The PI?s group has developed a combined method of optical spectroscopy, nanoelectrochemistry, and imaging techniques and Multiphysics computational simulation models for understanding the local redox events of a catalytic surface. The intellectual merits of this project include the successful demonstration of single nanoparticle electroluminescence and light scattering method for investigating local catalyzed redox reactions of chemical fuels at single metallic nanoparticles that are capable of catalyzing chemiluminescence and chemical fuel transformations. The team also investigated particle size and shape dependence of single NPs local electrochemical events with a nanoelectrode method that provides electrochemical information beyond the optical diffraction limit. The method has been applied to semiconductor nanostructures such as perovskite nanoparticles and two-dimensional materials. Local electrochemical reaction and its temporal and spatial heterogeneities can be studied with the method when interfaced with an advanced electrochemical imaging technique. The Broader impacts lie in the extensive outreach efforts focused on integrating the research project with education and training of high school teachers as well as education module development. Students involved in this project have been part of an interdisciplinary team and cross-trained in the areas of spectroelectrochemistry and material science. This ward has been acknowledged by 23 peer-reviewed journal publications and 34 conference presentations from the PI's group. 3 graduate students received excellent training and completed their doctoral training. This award also supported 9 undergraduates including 3 REU students, 1 visiting scholar, and 5 high school teachers from the State of Alabama to participate in electrochemistry research and professional training to advance their skills. The research infrastructure and electrochemistry instrument capability obtained through this award will benefit future research directions of molecular sensing and clean energy technologies and high-level professional workforce training in an interdisciplinary research area.
